case_name: Petitions Nos. 120-122, 164, 199, 213, 255, 260, 363, 378, 402, 407 of 1955 and connected petitions

facts.text: 32 petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution challenging constitutional validity of Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954).

anchor.surface_text: By each of these 32 petitions under Art. 32 of our Constitution, which have been heard together, the respective petitioners challenge the constitutional validity of the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953. Himachal 15 of 1954 which is said, to have been passed by the,.Legislative Assembly of the State of Himachal Pradesh created by the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act 32 of 1954 .

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954) passed by Legislative Assembly of State of Himachal Pradesh created by Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act 32 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953. Himachal 15 of 1954 which is said, to have been passed by the,.Legislative Assembly of the State of Himachal Pradesh created by the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act 32 of 1954 . On November 23, 1954, the President of India gave his assent to the Bill which on being so assented to became the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953, Himachal 15 of 1954 hereinafter called the Abolition Act .

facts.text: President of India gave assent to the Bill on November 23, 1954, making it Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954).

anchor.surface_text: On November 23, 1954, the President of India gave his assent to the Bill which on being so assented to became the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953, Himachal 15 of 1954 hereinafter called the Abolition Act . On January 26, 1955, this Abolition Act was brought into force by a notification issued under s. 1(3) thereof.

facts.text: Abolition Act brought into force on January 26, 1955 by notification under section 1(3).

anchor.surface_text: On January 26, 1955, this Abolition Act was brought into force by a notification issued under s. 1(3) thereof. It will be convenient at this stage to refer to some of the relevant sections of the Abolition Act.

facts.text: Petitioners are all landowners who moved court under Art 32 for enforcement of fundamental rights to properties.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, not surprising that the petitioners in all these petitions, all of whom are landowners, have moved this Court by separate petitions under Art. 32 for the enforcement of their fundamental rights to their respective properties.

facts.text: Two broad points raised: Abolition Act void for not passed by duly constituted legislature; provisions of Ch. III and Ch. VIII repugnant to Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In each of the several petitions which have been heard together two broad points have been taken, namely- That the Abolition Act is entirely void by reason of its not having been passed by a duly constituted legislature and That, in any event, the provisions of Ch. III and of Ch. VIII are repugnant to the Constitution.

facts.text: In First Schedule to Constitution, Bilaspur shown as item 3 and Himachal Pradesh as item 7 under Part C States.

anchor.surface_text: Re (i) In the First Schedule to the Constitution, as it was originally passed, were set out under the heading Part C States the names of 10 States. In that list of Part C States Bilaspur was shown as item 3 and Himachal Pradesh as item 7.

facts.text: Government of Part C States Act 49 of 1951 excludes Bilaspur, applies to old Himachal Pradesh with 36 seats in Legislative Assembly per Third Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Part C States Act 49 of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Part C States Act , provides for Legislative Assemblies... According to the Third Schedule, as it stood originally, the total number of seats allocated to the old Himachal Pradesh was 36 including 8 seats reserved for scheduled castes.

facts.text: Elections held in 1952 to Legislative Assembly of old Himachal Pradesh, 36 members elected.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred on him by s. 4 of the Part C States Act, the President duly made an order, determining the constituencies into which the old Himachal Pradesh would be divided and thereafter in 1952 elections were duly held and 36 members were elected by the voters of the different constituencies so delimited.

facts.text: Every member of Legislative Assembly of old Himachal Pradesh made and subscribed oath under s.14 Part C States Act before taking seat; Shri Jaiwant Ram elected Speaker.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute that... every member of that Legislative Assembly before taking his seat made and subscribed the usual oath or affirmation under s. 14 of the Part C States Act and elected one of the members Shri Jaiwant Ram as the Speaker and that the first session of the Assembly so constituted commenced functioning as the Legislative Assembly of the old Himachal Pradesh.

facts.text: Bill (Himachal 15 of 1953) introduced in first session of Legislative Assembly of old Himachal Pradesh in 1953, became Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was in this first session of this Legislative Assembly of the old Himachal Pradesh that in 1953 a Bill Himachal 15 of 1953 which became the Abolition Act was introduced.

facts.text: Parliament enacted Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act 32 of 1954 on May 8, 1954; President assent May 28, 1954; into force July 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the passage of that bill into an Act Parliament, on May 8, 1954, enacted an Act called the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act 32 of 1954 , hereinafter referred to as the New State Act . This Act received the assent of the President on May 28, 1954, and was brought into force by a notification, dated July 1, 1954...

facts.text: New State Act created new Part C State Himachal Pradesh by uniting old Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the New State Act says As from the commencement of this Act there shall be formed by uniting the existing States a new Part C State to be known as the State of Himachal Pradesh hereafter in this Act referred to as the new State .

facts.text: New State Act provides Legislative Assembly for new State with 41 seats filled by direct election.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 provides as follows 12. (1) There shall be a Legislative Assembly for the new State. The total number of seats in that Legislative Assembly which shall be filled by direct election shall be 41.

facts.text: Section 15(1) New State Act: sitting members of old Himachal Pradesh Assembly deemed elected to new Assembly for same constituencies.

anchor.surface_text: 15. (1) Every sitting member of the Legislative Assembly of the existing State of -Himachal Pradesh representing a constituency of the said State shall, on and from the commencement of this Act, represent the constituency of the same name in the new State and shall be deemed to have been elected to the Legislative Assembly of the new State by that constituency.

facts.text: Five members elected from Bilaspur area constituencies on May 13, 1955, bringing total to 41.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on May 13, 1955, five members were elected by the voters of the constituencies of that area so delimited so as to bring up the total number of members of the new Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh to 41 as prescribed by s. 12 of the New State Act.

facts.text: Notification dated July 7, 1954 summoning second session of Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly from August 16, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, on July 7, 1954, to be precise, the following notification was issued in the official Gazette- Legislative Assembly NOTIFICATION Simla-4, the 7th July, 1954. No. L.A.-109-28/54-The Lieutenant Governor... Second Session, 1954, of the Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly will commence from Monday, the 16th August, 1954...

facts.text: No notification declaring 36 members of old Assembly as members of new Assembly or constituting new Assembly before summoning notification.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that, prior to the date of the aforesaid notification summoning the Legislative Assembly, no notification was issued by the appropriate authority declaring the 36 persons who had been the members of the old Legislative Assembly of the old Himachal Pradesh as members of the new Legislative Assembly of the New Himachal Pradesh...

facts.text: 36 members of old Assembly did not make fresh oath or affirmation as members of new Assembly; no election of Speaker for new Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it in dispute that the 36 members of the old Legislative Assembly of the old Himachal Pradesh did not, in point of fact, make or subscribe any fresh oath or affirmation as members of the new Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh as required by s. 14 of the Part C States Act...

facts.text: Court finding: Legislative Assembly that passed Abolition Act was not the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh; Act not validly enacted.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the so called Legislative Assembly which was convened and which purported to pass the Abolition Act was not the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh created by the New State Act, therefore, the impugned Act cannot be regarded as a piece of validity enacted legislation.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 10, 1958 by DAS, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS, C. J.-

facts.text: Petitions heard together.

holdings.text: the so called Legislative Assembly which was convened and which purported to pass the Abolition Act was not the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh created by the New State Act, therefore, the impugned Act cannot be regarded as a piece of validity enacted legislation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the so called Legislative Assembly which was convened and which purported to pass the Abolition Act was not the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh created by the New State Act, therefore, the impugned Act cannot be regarded as a piece

holdings.reasoning_summary: No notification under s.74 RP Act constituting new assembly; no fresh oath under s.14 Part C States Act; no speaker election under s.10; summoning notification called it 'second session' indicating continuation of old assembly.

holdings.text: Section 15(1) of the New State Act deems the 36 sitting members elected but does not constitute the Legislative Assembly; post-election formalities such as notification under s.74 Representation of the People Act, oath under s.14 Part C States Act, and speaker election under s.10 are still required.

anchor.surface_text: By the operation of the deeming provision embodied in s. 15(1) the 36 members have been placed in the same position as they would have been placed in had they gone through the entire process of election and had been returned elected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming provision obviates election process but statutory fiction does not dispense with subsequent legal requirements to form and activate the assembly.

holdings.text: Sections 15(3) and 35 of Part C States Act do not cure the defects because there was no Legislative Assembly duly constituted and brought into existence at all.

anchor.surface_text: The discussion whether these irregularities can or cannot be cured under s. 15(3) and s. 35 of Part C States Act is not relevant at this stage. Assuming that the word vacancy

holdings.reasoning_summary: Curative provisions presuppose existence of a constituted assembly; they address irregularities or vacancies within an existing assembly, not failure to constitute one.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the so called Legislative Assembly which was convened and which purported to pass the Abolition Act was number the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh created by the New State Act, therefore, the impugned Act cannot be regarded as a piece of validity enacted legislation. That being the position the interference with the rights of the petitioners in and. to their respective properties cannot be for a moment be justified or permitted and the first question raised on behalf of the petitioners must be answered in their favour.

outcome.relief_summary: Impugned Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 held not a validly enacted legislation as passed by improperly constituted Legislative Assembly; interference with petitioners' property rights unjustified; first question answered in petitioners' favour; no need to examine second question.
